name: Definition of Variable
statement: A variable is a symbol that represents a quantity that can change or vary.
formal: Variable: A symbol representing a changing quantity.

name: Definition of Constant
statement: A constant is a fixed value that does not change.
formal: Constant: A value that remains unchanged.

name: Definition of Term
statement: A term is a number, a variable, or the product of numbers and variables.
formal: Term: A number, variable, or a product of both.

name: Definition of Coefficient
statement: A coefficient is the numerical factor of a term that contains a variable.
formal: Coefficient: Numerical factor of a variable term.

name: Definition of Expression
statement: An expression is a mathematical phrase that can contain numbers, variables, and operation symbols.
formal: Expression: A combination of numbers, variables, and operations.

name: Evaluation of Expressions
statement: Evaluating an expression means finding its value by substituting given numbers for variables.
formal: Evaluation: Substitute values into variables and compute.

name: Definition of Like Terms
statement: Like terms are terms that have exactly the same variable factors.
formal: Like Terms: Terms with identical variable parts.

name: Combining Like Terms
statement: Like terms can be combined by adding or subtracting their coefficients.
formal: If terms are like, add or subtract coefficients.

name: Distributive Property
statement: The distributive property states that a(b + c) = ab + ac for any numbers a, b, and c.
formal: a(b + c) = ab + ac

name: Simplification of Expressions
statement: Simplifying an expression means writing it in the simplest form by applying operations and combining like terms.
formal: Simplification: Apply operations and combine like terms.

name: Addition Property of Equality
statement: Adding the same value to both sides of an equation preserves equality.
formal: If a = b, then a + c = b + c.

name: Subtraction Property of Equality
statement: Subtracting the same value from both sides of an equation preserves equality.
formal: If a = b, then a - c = b - c.

name: Multiplication Property of Equality
statement: Multiplying both sides of an equation by the same nonzero value preserves equality.
formal: If a = b, then ac = bc, where c ≠ 0.

name: Division Property of Equality
statement: Dividing both sides of an equation by the same nonzero value preserves equality.
formal: If a = b, then a/c = b/c, where c ≠ 0.

name: Definition of Solution to an Equation
statement: A solution to an equation makes both sides of the equation equal when substituted into the equation.
formal: Substituting the solution into the equation yields a true statement.

name: Solving a Linear Equation
statement: To solve a linear equation, isolate the variable by performing inverse operations.
formal: Use inverse operations to isolate the variable.

name: Identity Equation
statement: An identity is an equation that is true for all values of the variable.
formal: An identity holds for all values in the domain.

name: Contradiction Equation
statement: A contradiction is an equation that is false for all values of the variable.
formal: A contradiction has no solution.

name: Transitive Property of Equality
statement: If a = b and b = c, then a = c.
formal: a = b and b = c ⇒ a = c

name: Substitution Property of Equality
statement: If two values are equal, one can be substituted for the other in any expression.
formal: If a = b, then a can replace b in any expression.

name: Definition of Opposite
statement: The opposite of a number is the number with the same absolute value but opposite sign.
formal: Opposite of a is -a.

name: Definition of Reciprocal
statement: The reciprocal of a nonzero number a is 1 divided by a.
formal: Reciprocal of a (a ≠ 0) is 1/a.

name: Multiplicative Inverse Property
statement: The product of a number and its reciprocal is 1.

name: Additive Inverse Property
statement: The sum of a number and its opposite is 0.

name: Commutative Property of Addition
statement: Changing the order of addends does not change the sum.
formal: a + b = b + a

name: Commutative Property of Multiplication
statement: Changing the order of factors does not change the product.
formal: ab = ba

name: Associative Property of Addition
statement: The grouping of addends does not change the sum.
formal: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)

name: Associative Property of Multiplication
statement: The grouping of factors does not change the product.
formal: (ab)c = a(bc)

name: Distributive Property over Addition
statement: Multiplying a sum by a number gives the same result as multiplying each addend by the number and then adding.
formal: a(b + c) = ab + ac

name: Simplifying Expressions with Distributive Property
statement: To simplify expressions with parentheses, apply the distributive property first, then combine like terms.
formal: Expand parentheses using distributive law, then combine like terms.

name: Multiplying Integers with Same Sign
statement: The product of two integers with the same sign is positive.
formal: If a and b have the same sign, then ab > 0.

name: Multiplying Integers with Different Signs
statement: The product of two integers with different signs is negative.
formal: If a and b have different signs, then ab < 0.

name: Dividing Integers with Same Sign
statement: The quotient of two integers with the same sign is positive.
formal: If a and b have the same sign, then a ÷ b > 0.

name: Dividing Integers with Different Signs
statement: The quotient of two integers with different signs is negative.
formal: If a and b have different signs, then a ÷ b < 0.

name: Order of Operations (PEMDAS)
statement: When simplifying expressions, perform operations in the order: Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication and Division (from left to right), Addition and Subtraction (from left to right).
formal: Follow the order: Parentheses → Exponents → Multiplication/Division → Addition/Subtraction.

name: Exponent of 0
statement: Any nonzero number raised to the power of 0 is 1.

name: Exponent of 1
statement: Any number raised to the power of 1 is the number itself.

name: Product of Powers Property
statement: When multiplying two powers with the same base, add the exponents.
formal: a^m × a^n = a^{m+n}

name: Power of a Power Property
statement: When raising a power to another power, multiply the exponents.
formal: (a^m)^n = a^{mn}

name: Power of a Product Property
statement: When raising a product to a power, raise each factor to the power.
formal: (ab)^n = a^n × b^n

name: Quotient of Powers Property
statement: When dividing two powers with the same base, subtract the exponents.
formal: a^m ÷ a^n = a^{m-n}, where a ≠ 0.

name: Negative Exponent Rule
statement: A nonzero number raised to a negative exponent equals the reciprocal of the number raised to the opposite positive exponent.
formal: a^{-n} = 1/a^n, where a ≠ 0.

name: Zero Rule for Multiplication
statement: Any number multiplied by zero equals zero.

name: Division by Zero Undefined
statement: Division by zero is undefined.
formal: a ÷ 0 is undefined.

name: Simplifying Complex Expressions
statement: When simplifying complex expressions, apply order of operations, properties of exponents, and combine like terms where possible.
formal: Apply PEMDAS, exponent laws, and like terms combination in order.

name: Definition of Absolute Value
statement: The absolute value of a number is its distance from zero on the number line.
formal: |a| = a if a ≥ 0, and |a| = -a if a < 0.

name: Properties of Absolute Value
statement: Absolute value properties: |ab| = |a||b|, |a/b| = |a|/|b| (b ≠ 0), and |a| ≥ 0.

name: Definition of Rational Numbers
statement: Rational numbers are numbers that can be expressed as a fraction a/b where a and b are integers and b ≠ 0.
formal: Rational Number: a/b, where a, b ∈ ℤ, b ≠ 0.

name: Definition of Irrational Numbers
statement: Irrational numbers are real numbers that cannot be expressed as a fraction of two integers.
formal: Irrational Number: Real number not expressible as a/b where a, b ∈ ℤ, b ≠ 0.

name: Additive Identity Property
statement: The additive identity property states that a number plus zero is the number itself.

name: Multiplicative Identity Property
statement: The multiplicative identity property states that a number multiplied by one is the number itself.

name: Closure Property of Addition
statement: The sum of any two integers (or rational numbers) is an integer (or rational number).
formal: If a, b ∈ ℤ (or ℚ), then a + b ∈ ℤ (or ℚ).

name: Closure Property of Multiplication
statement: The product of any two integers (or rational numbers) is an integer (or rational number).
formal: If a, b ∈ ℤ (or ℚ), then ab ∈ ℤ (or ℚ).

name: Substitution Principle
statement: If two values are equal, one can be substituted for the other in any expression without changing the value.
formal: If a = b, then a can replace b in any expression.

name: Definition of Real Numbers
statement: Real numbers consist of all rational and irrational numbers.
formal: ℝ = ℚ ∪ (irrational numbers).

name: Definition of Polynomial Expression
statement: A polynomial expression is a sum of terms consisting of variables raised to non-negative integer exponents and multiplied by coefficients.
formal: Polynomial: Sum of terms ax^n where a ∈ ℝ and n ∈ ℕ₀.

name: Extended Definition of Like Terms
statement: Like terms are terms that have exactly the same variable factors with the same exponents.
formal: Like Terms: Identical variables with identical exponents.

name: Combining Like Terms Rule
statement: Like terms can be combined by adding or subtracting their coefficients while keeping the variable part unchanged.
formal: If terms are like, add or subtract coefficients; variable part remains the same.

name: Distributive Property over Subtraction
statement: The distributive property applies to subtraction: a(b - c) = ab - ac.
formal: a(b - c) = ab - ac

name: Simplifying Nested Parentheses
statement: When simplifying expressions with nested parentheses, expand from the innermost set outward, applying distributive property at each step.
formal: Expand innermost parentheses first, then outward, using distributive law.

name: Coefficient Manipulation Rule
statement: When combining terms, operate only on the coefficients, not on the variable parts.
formal: Coefficients are added or subtracted; variables remain unchanged.

name: Addition and Subtraction of Unlike Terms
statement: Unlike terms cannot be combined; they must remain separate in the simplified expression.
formal: Unlike terms cannot be combined through addition or subtraction.

name: General Simplification Strategy
statement: When simplifying expressions, first remove parentheses, then combine like terms, and finally perform any remaining operations.
formal: Simplification order: Expand parentheses → Combine like terms → Final operations.

name: Definition of Two-Variable Equation
statement: A two-variable linear equation is an equation that can be written in the form ax + by = c, where a, b, and c are real numbers and at least one of a or b is nonzero.
formal: ax + by = c where a, b, c ∈ ℝ and (a, b) ≠ (0, 0).

name: Solution of Two-Variable Equation
statement: A solution of a two-variable equation is an ordered pair (x, y) that makes the equation true when substituted.
formal: If ax + by = c after substituting (x, y), then (x, y) is a solution.

name: Substitution Principle for Two Variables
statement: If a variable is expressed in terms of another, it can be substituted into an equation to reduce the number of variables.
formal: If y = f(x), then substitute f(x) for y.

name: Solving for a Variable in Two-Variable Equation
statement: To solve for a variable in a two-variable equation, isolate the target variable using inverse operations.
formal: Use inverse operations to express one variable in terms of the other.

name: Rearrangement Property
statement: Terms can be moved to the other side of an equation by applying the opposite operation to both sides.
formal: a + b = c ⇨ a = c - b, and similar rearrangements.

name: Symmetric Property of Equality
statement: If a = b, then b = a.
formal: a = b ⇨ b = a.

name: Definition of Ratio
statement: A ratio is a comparison of two quantities by division.
formal: Ratio of a to b is a/b, where b ≠ 0.

name: Definition of Proportion
statement: A proportion is an equation that states two ratios are equal.
formal: Proportion: a/b = c/d, where b ≠ 0 and d ≠ 0.

name: Cross Multiplication Property
statement: If two ratios are equal, then the cross products are equal: a/b = c/d implies ad = bc.
formal: If a/b = c/d, then ad = bc.

name: Scaling Property of Ratios
statement: Multiplying or dividing both terms of a ratio by the same nonzero number does not change the ratio.
formal: a/b = (ka)/(kb), where k ≠ 0.

name: Solving Proportion Rule
statement: To solve a proportion, cross-multiply and solve the resulting equation.
formal: From a/b = c/d, deduce ad = bc and solve for the unknown.

name: Definition of Unit Rate
statement: A unit rate compares a quantity to one unit of another quantity.
formal: Unit rate: a quantity expressed per 1 unit.

name: Definition of Slope
statement: The slope of a line measures the steepness of the line and is the ratio of the vertical change to the horizontal change between two points on the line.
formal: Slope m = (change in y)/(change in x) = (y₂ - y₁)/(x₂ - x₁), x₁ ≠ x₂.

name: Definition of y-Intercept
statement: The y-intercept of a line is the point where the line crosses the y-axis.
formal: The y-coordinate when x = 0.

name: Slope Formula Between Two Points
statement: The slope between two distinct points (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂) is given by m = (y₂ - y₁)/(x₂ - x₁).
formal: m = (y₂ - y₁)/(x₂ - x₁), x₁ ≠ x₂.

name: Equation of Line (Slope and Intercept Form)
statement: The equation of a line with slope m and y-intercept b is y = mx + b.
formal: y = mx + b.

name: Equation of Line Given Two Points
statement: To find the equation of a line given two points, first find the slope using the slope formula, then use point-slope form to derive the equation.
formal: Use m = (y₂ - y₁)/(x₂ - x₁), then y - y₁ = m(x - x₁).

name: Horizontal and Vertical Line Interpretation
statement: A horizontal line has equation y = constant and slope 0. A vertical line has equation x = constant and undefined slope.
formal: Horizontal: y = k (m = 0); Vertical: x = k (slope undefined).

name: Definition of Inequality Symbols
statement: The inequality symbols <, ≤, >, and ≥ represent 'less than', 'less than or equal to', 'greater than', and 'greater than or equal to', respectively.
formal: <: less than, ≤: less than or equal to, >: greater than, ≥: greater than or equal to.

name: Addition and Subtraction Property of Inequalities
statement: Adding or subtracting the same number on both sides of an inequality does not change the direction of the inequality.
formal: If a < b, then a + c < b + c and a - c < b - c.

name: Multiplication and Division Property of Inequalities
statement: When multiplying or dividing both sides of an inequality by a positive number, the inequality direction remains the same. When multiplying or dividing by a negative number, the inequality direction reverses.
formal: If a < b and c > 0, then ac < bc. If c < 0, then ac > bc.

name: Solving Inequalities by Inverse Operations
statement: To solve an inequality, isolate the variable using inverse operations, carefully adjusting the direction of the inequality if multiplying or dividing by a negative number.
formal: Apply inverse operations; flip inequality if multiplying/dividing by negative.

name: Compound Inequalities Rule
statement: A compound inequality consists of two inequalities joined by 'and' or 'or' and can be solved by solving each part individually.
formal: Solve each inequality separately, then find the intersection (and) or union (or) of solutions.

name: Definition of Quadratic Expression
statement: A quadratic expression is a polynomial expression of degree 2, typically written as ax² + bx + c, where a, b, and c are real numbers and a ≠ 0.
formal: Quadratic Expression: ax² + bx + c where a ≠ 0.

name: Definition of Quadratic Equation
statement: A quadratic equation is an equation that can be written in the form ax² + bx + c = 0, where a, b, and c are real numbers and a ≠ 0.
formal: Quadratic Equation: ax² + bx + c = 0 where a ≠ 0.

name: Definition of Square Root
statement: The square root of a non-negative number a is the non-negative number x such that x² = a.
formal: If x ≥ 0 and x² = a, then x = √a.

name: Solving Simple Quadratic Equations
statement: To solve an equation of the form x² = a, take the positive and negative square roots: x = ±√a.
formal: If x² = a, then x = ±√a.

name: Principle of Two Solutions for Square Roots
statement: An equation of the form x² = a (for a > 0) has exactly two real solutions: √a and -√a.
formal: Solutions are x = √a and x = -√a.

name: Definition of Factoring
statement: Factoring is the process of writing a mathematical expression as a product of its factors.
formal: Rewrite an expression as a product of simpler expressions.

name: GCF Factoring Rule
statement: The greatest common factor (GCF) of all terms can be factored out from a polynomial.
formal: Factor out GCF common to all terms.

name: Factoring Quadratic Trinomials
statement: A quadratic trinomial ax² + bx + c can often be factored into the product of two binomials.
formal: ax² + bx + c = (dx + e)(fx + g), where d, e, f, g ∈ ℝ.

name: Factoring Perfect Square Trinomials
statement: A trinomial of the form a² + 2ab + b² can be factored as (a + b)², and a² - 2ab + b² can be factored as (a - b)².
formal: a² + 2ab + b² = (a+b)²; a² - 2ab + b² = (a-b)².

name: Factoring Difference of Squares
statement: An expression of the form a² - b² can be factored as (a + b)(a - b).
formal: a² - b² = (a+b)(a-b).

name: Definition of Imaginary Unit
statement: The imaginary unit i is defined as the number satisfying i² = -1.

name: Definition of Complex Number
statement: A complex number is a number of the form a + bi, where a and b are real numbers and i is the imaginary unit.
formal: Complex Number: a + bi where a, b ∈ ℝ.

name: Addition and Subtraction of Complex Numbers
statement: To add or subtract complex numbers, add or subtract their real parts and their imaginary parts separately.
formal: (a + bi) ± (c + di) = (a ± c) + (b ± d)i.

name: Multiplication of Complex Numbers
statement: To multiply two complex numbers, apply the distributive property and use the fact that i² = -1.
formal: (a + bi)(c + di) = (ac - bd) + (ad + bc)i.

name: Powers of i Rule
statement: The powers of i cycle every 4: i¹ = i, i² = -1, i³ = -i, i⁴ = 1, and repeat.
formal: i¹ = i, i² = -1, i³ = -i, i⁴ = 1, and cycle repeats.

name: Definition of Completing the Square
statement: Completing the square is the process of rewriting a quadratic expression as a perfect square trinomial plus or minus a constant.
formal: Rewrite ax² + bx + c as (x + d)² + e or a variant after adjustment.

name: Completing the Square Formula (Monic Quadratic)
statement: For a monic quadratic expression x² + bx, completing the square involves adding (b/2)² to form (x + b/2)².
formal: x² + bx = (x + b/2)² - (b/2)² + bx.

name: Completing the Square for Non-Monic Quadratics
statement: For a quadratic with leading coefficient a ≠ 1, divide through by a before completing the square.
formal: ax² + bx + c → (x + b/2a)² after dividing by a.

name: Solving Quadratic Equations by Completing the Square
statement: To solve a quadratic by completing the square, complete the square, isolate the squared term, and take the square root of both sides.
formal: Complete square → isolate square term → apply ±√.

name: Perfect Square Recognition Rule
statement: An expression of the form (x + d)² or (x - d)² is a perfect square trinomial.
formal: (x + d)² = x² + 2dx + d².

name: Definition of Parabola
statement: The graph of a quadratic function y = ax² + bx + c is called a parabola.
formal: A parabola is the graph of a function y = ax² + bx + c where a ≠ 0.

name: Direction of Parabola
statement: If a > 0, the parabola opens upward. If a < 0, the parabola opens downward.
formal: a > 0 → opens upward; a < 0 → opens downward.

name: Vertex Formula
statement: The vertex of the parabola y = ax² + bx + c occurs at x = -b/(2a).
formal: Vertex x-coordinate: x = -b/(2a).

name: Axis of Symmetry
statement: The axis of symmetry of a parabola is the vertical line that passes through its vertex.
formal: Axis of symmetry: x = -b/(2a).

name: Maximum and Minimum Value of Parabola
statement: If the parabola opens upward, the vertex represents the minimum value. If it opens downward, the vertex represents the maximum value.
formal: a > 0 → vertex is minimum; a < 0 → vertex is maximum.

name: Definition of Function
statement: A function is a relation that assigns exactly one output value to each input value.
formal: For each input x, there is exactly one output y.

name: Definition of Function Notation
statement: Function notation f(x) represents the output value of function f corresponding to input x.
formal: f(x) denotes the output when the input is x.

name: Finding Function Values
statement: To find the value of a function at a given input, substitute the input value into the function expression.
formal: Evaluate f(a) by substituting a for x in f(x).

name: Definition of Domain and Range
statement: The domain of a function is the set of all possible input values, and the range is the set of all possible output values.
formal: Domain: all possible x-values; Range: all possible f(x)-values.

name: Distinguishing Functions from Relations
statement: A relation is a function if and only if no input value maps to more than one output value.
formal: Each x corresponds to exactly one y for a relation to be a function.

name: Translation of Graphs
statement: Translating a graph horizontally by h units and vertically by k units shifts the graph of y = f(x) to y = f(x-h) + k.
formal: Translation: y = f(x-h) + k shifts graph right h units and up k units.

name: Reflection Across Axes
statement: Reflecting a graph across the x-axis transforms y = f(x) to y = -f(x). Reflecting across the y-axis transforms y = f(x) to y = f(-x).
formal: Reflection: x-axis → y = -f(x); y-axis → y = f(-x).

name: Vertical Stretch and Compression
statement: Multiplying the output of a function by a factor a stretches or compresses the graph vertically: y = af(x).
formal: Vertical Stretch: a > 1; Vertical Compression: 0 < a < 1.

name: Horizontal Stretch and Compression
statement: Multiplying the input of a function by a factor b stretches or compresses the graph horizontally: y = f(bx).
formal: Horizontal Compression: b > 1; Horizontal Stretch: 0 < b < 1.

name: Combined Transformations
statement: When multiple transformations are applied, perform horizontal transformations first, then reflections, stretches/compressions, and finally vertical translations.
formal: Order: Horizontal shift → Reflection/stretch/compression → Vertical shift.

name: Addition and Subtraction of Polynomials
statement: To add or subtract polynomials, combine like terms by adding or subtracting their coefficients.
formal: Group like terms and perform addition or subtraction of coefficients.

name: Multiplication of a Monomial and a Polynomial
statement: To multiply a monomial by a polynomial, apply the distributive property to each term of the polynomial.
formal: Distribute the monomial to each term inside the parentheses.

name: Multiplication of Two Polynomials
statement: To multiply two polynomials, apply the distributive property across all terms: each term in the first polynomial multiplies every term in the second polynomial.
formal: Apply distributive property fully: (a+b)(c+d) = ac + ad + bc + bd.

name: Recognition of Special Products
statement: Recognize and simplify common special products like perfect square trinomials and difference of squares when expanding polynomials.
formal: Identify patterns such as (a+b)² and (a+b)(a-b).

name: Definition of Mean
statement: The mean of a data set is the sum of all data values divided by the number of values.
formal: Mean = (sum of data values) / (number of data values).

name: Definition of Median
statement: The median of a data set is the middle value when the data are arranged in order. If there are an even number of values, the median is the mean of the two middle values.
formal: Median = middle value or average of two middle values after ordering.

name: Definition of Mode
statement: The mode of a data set is the value or values that occur most frequently.
formal: Mode = value(s) occurring with highest frequency.

name: Definition of Range
statement: The range of a data set is the difference between the greatest and least data values.
formal: Range = maximum value - minimum value.

name: Interpretation of Data Sets
statement: Interpretation of a data set involves analyzing measures such as mean, median, mode, and range to describe the distribution.
formal: Use measures of center and spread to describe data distribution.

name: Product of Powers Property
statement: When multiplying two expressions with the same base, add the exponents.
formal: a^m × a^n = a^{m+n}, where a ≠ 0.

name: Power of a Power Property
statement: When raising a power to another power, multiply the exponents.
formal: (a^m)^n = a^{mn}, where a ≠ 0.

name: Negative Exponent Property
statement: A negative exponent represents the reciprocal of the base raised to the positive exponent.
formal: a^{-n} = 1/a^n, where a ≠ 0.

name: Definition of Rational Exponent
statement: A rational exponent represents a root: a^{1/n} is the nth root of a.
formal: a^{1/n} = √[n]{a}, where a ≥ 0 for real numbers.

name: Radical Multiplication and Division Rules
statement: The product or quotient of radicals can be written as the radical of the product or quotient.
formal: √a × √b = √(ab), √(a/b) = √a/√b, where a, b ≥ 0 and b ≠ 0.

name: Definition of Arithmetic Sequence
statement: An arithmetic sequence is a sequence of numbers in which the difference between consecutive terms is constant.
formal: Arithmetic Sequence: a_n = a_1 + (n-1)d where d is the common difference.

name: Definition of Geometric Sequence
statement: A geometric sequence is a sequence of numbers in which each term after the first is found by multiplying the previous term by a constant called the common ratio.
formal: Geometric Sequence: a_n = a_1 × r^(n-1) where r is the common ratio.

name: Formula for nth Term of Arithmetic Sequence
statement: The nth term of an arithmetic sequence can be found using the formula a_n = a_1 + (n-1)d, where a_1 is the first term and d is the common difference.

name: Formula for nth Term of Geometric Sequence
statement: The nth term of a geometric sequence can be found using the formula a_n = a_1 × r^(n-1), where a_1 is the first term and r is the common ratio.

name: Sum Formula for Arithmetic Sequence
statement: The sum of the first n terms of an arithmetic sequence can be calculated using the formula S_n = n/2 × (a_1 + a_n), where a_1 is the first term and a_n is the nth term.

name: Definition of Probability
statement: Probability is the measure of the likelihood of an event, calculated as the ratio of favorable outcomes to the total number of possible outcomes.
formal: P(A) = favorable outcomes / total outcomes.

name: Simple Probability Formula
statement: The probability of a simple event is the ratio of the number of favorable outcomes to the total number of possible outcomes.
formal: P(A) = number of favorable outcomes / total number of outcomes.

name: Combination Formula (nCr)
statement: The number of ways to choose r objects from n distinct objects without regard to order is given by the combination formula: nCr = n! / (r!(n-r)!)
formal: nCr = n! / (r!(n-r)!)

name: Probability of Simple Events
statement: The probability of simple events can be calculated using the simple probability formula.
formal: P(simple event) = favorable outcomes / total outcomes.

name: Complementary Events Rule
statement: The probability of the complement of an event A is given by P(A') = 1 - P(A).

name: Types of Graphs
statement: Graphs can be categorized into bar graphs, line graphs, pie charts, and histograms, each serving different purposes for data representation.
formal: Bar graphs, line graphs, pie charts, and histograms are different ways to represent data visually.

name: Graphing Data
statement: Graphing data involves plotting data points on a coordinate plane and connecting them using appropriate graph types based on the data.
formal: Plot data points and connect them using a bar, line, or pie chart depending on the context of the data.

name: Graph Interpretation
statement: Interpreting graphs involves analyzing the relationships between variables, trends, and patterns in the data.
formal: Examine the graph to interpret relationships between data points and identify trends.

name: Relationship Between Variables in Graphs
statement: The relationship between variables in graphs can be observed through the slope, direction, and shape of the graph.
formal: Analyze the slope, direction, and shape of the graph to understand the relationship between the variables.

name: Zero-Product Property
statement: If the product of two expressions is zero, then at least one of the expressions is zero.
formal: If A·B = 0, then A = 0 or B = 0.

title: Closure Property of Real Numbers
content: The set of real numbers is closed under addition and multiplication. If x and y are real, then x + y and xy are also real.

title: Commutative Property
content: Changing the order of the numbers does not change the result: x + y = y + x, and xy = yx.

title: Associative Property
content: Grouping does not affect the sum or product: (x + y) + z = x + (y + z), and (xy)z = x(yz).

title: Distributive Property
content: Multiplying a number by a sum is the same as multiplying each term and adding: x(y + z) = xy + xz.

title: Additive Identity
content: Adding 0 to any number does not change its value: x + 0 = x.

title: Multiplicative Identity
content: Multiplying a number by 1 does not change its value: x × 1 = x.

title: Additive Inverse
content: Every real number has an additive inverse: x + (−x) = 0.

title: Multiplicative Inverse
content: Every nonzero real number has a multiplicative inverse: x × (1/x) = 1 for x ≠ 0.

title: Real Number Line
content: The real number line is a continuous, infinite line representing all real numbers, where numbers to the left of 0 are negative and to the right are positive.

title: Absolute Value Definition
content: The absolute value |x| is the distance of x from 0 on the number line. It is always non-negative.

title: Distance Between Two Points
content: The distance between two real numbers a and b is given by |a - b|.

title: Evaluating Algebraic Expressions
content: To evaluate an algebraic expression, substitute known values for the variables and simplify.

title: Simplifying Algebraic Expressions
content: Combine like terms and apply arithmetic operations to simplify algebraic expressions.

title: Solving Linear Equations
content: To solve a linear equation, isolate the variable by performing inverse operations and simplifying both sides.

title: Golden Rule of Inequalities
content: When solving inequalities, reverse the inequality sign if both sides are multiplied or divided by a negative number.

title: Compound Inequalities
content: A compound inequality joins two inequalities with 'and' (conjunction) or 'or' (disjunction).

title: Absolute Value Equation
content: To solve |x - a| = b, split into two cases: x - a = b or x - a = -b.

title: Absolute Value Inequality (Less Than)
content: The inequality |x - a| < b is equivalent to a - b < x < a + b.

title: Absolute Value Inequality (Greater Than)
content: The inequality |x - a| > b is equivalent to x < a - b or x > a + b.

title: Definition of Relation
content: A relation is a set of ordered pairs (x, y) that shows how each input x is related to an output y.

title: Definition of Function
content: A function is a relation in which each input has exactly one output.

title: Vertical Line Test
content: If a vertical line intersects a graph more than once, the relation is not a function.

title: Domain and Range
content: The domain is the set of all possible inputs (x-values), and the range is the set of all possible outputs (y-values) of a function.

title: Direct Variation
content: If y varies directly with x, then y = kx for some constant k. The graph passes through the origin.

title: Slope-Intercept Form
content: The equation of a line in slope-intercept form is y = mx + b, where m is the slope and b is the y-intercept.

title: Interpretation of Slope
content: The slope of a line represents the rate of change of y with respect to x: m = (change in y) / (change in x).

title: Parallel and Perpendicular Slopes
content: Parallel lines have equal slopes. Perpendicular lines have slopes that are negative reciprocals of each other.

title: Point-Slope Form
content: The equation of a line with slope m passing through (x₁, y₁) is y - y₁ = m(x - x₁).

title: Function Transformation: Vertical Shift
content: The graph of y = f(x) + k shifts the graph of y = f(x) up by k units if k > 0, or down if k < 0.

title: Function Transformation: Horizontal Shift
content: The graph of y = f(x - h) shifts the graph of y = f(x) to the right by h units if h > 0, or left if h < 0.

title: Function Transformation: Reflection
content: The graph of y = -f(x) reflects y = f(x) across the x-axis; y = f(-x) reflects across the y-axis.

title: Function Transformation: Dilation
content: The graph of y = a·f(x) stretches vertically if |a| > 1, compresses if 0 < |a| < 1, and reflects if a < 0.

title: Absolute Value Function
content: The graph of y = |x| forms a 'V' shape with vertex at the origin. It is piecewise defined: y = x for x ≥ 0 and y = -x for x < 0.

title: Linear Inequality in Two Variables
content: A linear inequality such as y < mx + b represents a region of the plane. The boundary is dashed if the inequality is strict.

title: Conjunctive Inequality
content: A conjunctive inequality joins two conditions with 'and', meaning both must be true. It represents the intersection of the solution sets: a < x < b.

title: Disjunctive Inequality
content: A disjunctive inequality joins two conditions with 'or', meaning either can be true. It represents the union of the solution sets: x < a or x > b.

title: Consistent and Inconsistent Systems
content: A system of equations is consistent if it has at least one solution, and inconsistent if it has no solution.

title: Independent and Dependent Systems
content: A system is independent if it has exactly one solution. It is dependent if the equations represent the same line and have infinitely many solutions.

title: Substitution Method
content: Solve one equation for a variable and substitute that expression into the other equation to find the solution.

title: Elimination Method
content: Add or subtract equations to eliminate one variable and solve the resulting equation.

title: Graphical Solution of a System
content: The solution to a system of equations is the point(s) where their graphs intersect.

title: System of Linear Inequalities
content: A system of linear inequalities represents a region where the solutions of all inequalities overlap (feasible region).

title: Linear Programming
content: A method to find the maximum or minimum value of a linear objective function, subject to a set of linear constraints (inequalities).

title: Feasible Region
content: The solution region that satisfies all the inequalities in a system, often bounded by straight lines.

title: Vertex Optimization Principle
content: For a linear programming problem, the maximum or minimum value of the objective function occurs at a vertex of the feasible region.

title: System of Three Variables
content: A system of three equations with three unknowns can represent planes in 3D space and may intersect at a point, line, or not at all.

title: Standard Form of a Quadratic Function
content: A quadratic function can be written in the form y = ax² + bx + c, where a, b, and c are constants and a ≠ 0.

title: Vertex of a Parabola (Formula)
content: The vertex of the parabola y = ax² + bx + c is given by x = -b/(2a).

title: Axis of Symmetry
content: The axis of symmetry of a parabola y = ax² + bx + c is the vertical line x = -b/(2a).

title: Factored Form of a Quadratic
content: A quadratic can be factored as y = a(x - r₁)(x - r₂), where r₁ and r₂ are the roots (x-intercepts) of the function.

title: Vertex Form of a Quadratic
content: The vertex form of a quadratic is y = a(x - h)² + k, where (h, k) is the vertex of the parabola.

title: Completing the Square
content: To complete the square, rewrite ax² + bx as a(x² + (b/a)x) and add/subtract (b/2a)² to form a perfect square trinomial.

title: Quadratic Formula
content: The solutions to ax² + bx + c = 0 are x = [-b ± √(b² - 4ac)] / (2a).

title: Discriminant and Nature of Roots
content: The discriminant Δ = b² - 4ac determines the nature of the roots: two real and distinct (Δ > 0), one real (Δ = 0), or complex (Δ < 0).

title: Zero Product Property
content: If ab = 0, then either a = 0 or b = 0. Used to solve factored quadratic equations.

title: Solving Quadratic Equations by Factoring
content: To solve ax² + bx + c = 0, factor the expression and set each factor equal to zero using the Zero Product Property.

title: Complex Number Definition
content: A complex number is a number in the form a + bi, where a and b are real numbers and i² = -1.

title: Conjugate of a Complex Number
content: The conjugate of a + bi is a - bi. The product of a complex number and its conjugate is a² + b².

title: Application of Quadratic Functions
content: Quadratic functions are commonly used to model projectile motion, area problems, and optimization scenarios.

title: Maximum or Minimum of a Quadratic
content: For y = ax² + bx + c, if a > 0 the vertex is a minimum; if a < 0 the vertex is a maximum.

title: Word Problem Modeling with Quadratics
content: To solve word problems using quadratics, define variables, form an equation in standard or vertex form, and solve using factoring or the quadratic formula.

title: Solving Quadratic Inequalities
content: To solve ax² + bx + c < 0 or > 0, find roots, plot on number line, and test sign of expression in each interval.

title: Sign Chart for Quadratics
content: A sign chart shows where a quadratic expression is positive or negative by dividing the number line at its roots.

title: Graphical Interpretation of Quadratic Inequality
content: The solution set of a quadratic inequality corresponds to the portion of the graph of y = ax² + bx + c that lies above or below the x-axis.

title: Set Notation for Inequality Solutions
content: Solutions to inequalities can be written in set-builder or interval notation, depending on the required format.

title: Polynomial Definition
content: A polynomial is an expression consisting of variables and coefficients, involving only non-negative integer exponents and addition, subtraction, or multiplication.

title: Degree of a Polynomial
content: The degree of a polynomial is the highest power of the variable in the expression.

title: Leading Coefficient
content: The leading coefficient is the coefficient of the term with the highest degree in a polynomial.

title: End Behavior of Polynomial Functions
content: The end behavior of a polynomial function depends on the sign of the leading coefficient and the degree (even or odd).

title: Real Zeros of Polynomials
content: The real zeros of a polynomial function are the x-values for which the function equals zero; these correspond to x-intercepts of the graph.

title: Multiplicity of a Zero
content: If (x - r)^k is a factor of a polynomial, then r is a zero of multiplicity k. If k is even, the graph touches the axis; if odd, it crosses.

title: Polynomial Division: Long Division
content: Divide polynomials similarly to numbers by dividing leading terms, multiplying, subtracting, and repeating the process.

title: Synthetic Division
content: A shortcut method for dividing a polynomial by a linear factor of the form (x - c), using only coefficients.

title: Factor Theorem
content: If f(c) = 0, then (x - c) is a factor of the polynomial f(x).

title: Remainder Theorem
content: When a polynomial f(x) is divided by (x - c), the remainder is f(c).

title: Rational Root Theorem
content: If a rational root of a polynomial with integer coefficients exists, it must be a factor of the constant term over a factor of the leading coefficient.

title: Graph Behavior at Zeros
content: The shape of the graph near a zero depends on the zero's multiplicity: even multiplicities result in touching, odd in crossing.

title: Factoring Polynomials
content: To factor a polynomial, find a greatest common factor, then apply techniques such as grouping, special products, or division.

title: Special Factoring: Difference of Squares
content: a² - b² = (a - b)(a + b)

title: Special Factoring: Perfect Square Trinomial
content: a² ± 2ab + b² = (a ± b)²

title: Special Factoring: Sum and Difference of Cubes
content: a³ ± b³ = (a ± b)(a² ∓ ab + b²)

title: Guidelines for Finding Roots
content: Check rational roots using Rational Root Theorem, test values using synthetic division, then factor completely.

title: Using Graph to Estimate Zeros
content: Use a graph to visually locate approximate x-intercepts where the function crosses or touches the x-axis.

title: Polynomial Word Problem Setup
content: Define variables, construct a polynomial model for volume, area, or cost, then solve by factoring or substitution.

title: Polynomial Identity Verification
content: To verify an identity, expand both sides and simplify to check if they are equivalent.

title: Identifying Polynomial from Graph
content: Analyze a polynomial graph to determine its degree, leading coefficient sign, and possible multiplicity of real zeros.

title: Turning Points of a Polynomial
content: A polynomial of degree n has at most n - 1 turning points (local maxima or minima).

title: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra (Intro)
content: Every non-zero polynomial of degree n has exactly n complex roots (real and/or nonreal), counted with multiplicity.

title: Descartes’ Rule of Signs
content: The number of positive or negative real zeros of a polynomial can be estimated by counting sign changes in f(x) and f(-x).

title: Definition of Radical Expression
content: A radical expression is an expression that includes a root, such as a square root, cube root, or nth root.

title: Simplest Radical Form
content: A radical expression is in simplest form when there are no perfect square factors under the radical and no radicals in the denominator.

title: Product Rule for Radicals
content: For nonnegative real numbers a and b: √(ab) = √a × √b.

title: Quotient Rule for Radicals
content: For nonnegative real numbers a and b (b ≠ 0): √(a/b) = √a ÷ √b.

title: Rational Exponents
content: An expression like a^(m/n) means the nth root of a raised to the mth power: a^(m/n) = (ⁿ√a)^m.

title: Converting Between Radicals and Exponents
content: Use a^(m/n) = ⁿ√(a^m) or ⁿ√a = a^(1/n) to rewrite between forms.

title: Multiplying Radical Expressions
content: Multiply the coefficients and the radicands separately: √a × √b = √(ab), if both are nonnegative.

title: Rationalizing the Denominator
content: To eliminate radicals from the denominator, multiply numerator and denominator by a radical that removes the root from the bottom.

title: Solving Radical Equations
content: To solve radical equations, isolate the radical and square both sides. Always check for extraneous solutions.

title: Domain of Radical Functions
content: The domain of a radical function with even index includes only values where the radicand is nonnegative.

title: Definition of Radical Function
content: A radica function is a function that contains a variable inside a root, such as f(x) = √x or f(x) = ∛(x − 2).

title: Graph of a Square Root Function
content: The graph of f(x) = √x starts at (0, 0) and increases slowly to the right. Its domain is x ≥ 0, and range is y ≥ 0.

title: Transformation of Radical Functions
content: The function f(x) = a√(x − h) + k shifts the parent graph √x right h units, up k units, stretches by a if |a| > 1, and reflects if a < 0.

title: Even vs. Odd Index Radical Domains
content: Functions with even-index radicals (e.g., √x) require nonnegative radicands. Odd-index radicals (e.g., ∛x) have all real numbers as domain.

title: Definition of Rational Expression
content: A rational expression is a ratio of two polynomials, such as (x + 1)/(x − 2), where the denominator is not zero.

title: Domain of a Rational Expression
content: The domain excludes all values that make the denominator zero.

title: Simplifying Rational Expressions
content: To simplify a rational expression, factor both numerator and denominator and cancel common factors.

title: Multiplying and Dividing Rational Expressions
content: Multiply numerators and denominators directly; for division, multiply by the reciprocal of the second expression.

title: Adding and Subtracting Rational Expressions
content: To add or subtract rational expressions, find a common denominator, rewrite each expression, then combine numerators.

title: Solving Rational Equations
content: To solve rational equations, multiply both sides by a common denominator to eliminate fractions. Check for extraneous solutions.

title: Definition of Rational Function
content: A rational function is a function defined by a rational expression, such as f(x) = (x + 1)/(x − 3).

title: Vertical Asymptote
content: A vertical asymptote occurs at values that make the denominator zero and are not canceled by the numerator.

title: Hole in the Graph
content: A hole occurs at a value that makes both the numerator and denominator zero, indicating a removable discontinuity.

title: Graphing Rational Functions
content: To graph a rational function, find intercepts, asymptotes, and analyze behavior near discontinuities.

title: Horizontal Asymptote
content: A horizontal asymptote shows the end behavior of a rational function. Compare degrees of numerator and denominator to determine it.

title: Slant (Oblique) Asymptote
content: If the degree of the numerator is one more than the degree of the denominator, use polynomial division to find a slant asymptote.

title: End Behavior of Rational Functions
content: The end behavior of a rational function depends on the degrees of the numerator and denominator and determines the horizontal or slant asymptote.

title: Definition of Exponential Function
content: An exponential function is a function of the form f(x) = a·b^x where a ≠ 0 and b > 0, b ≠ 1.

title: Properties of Exponential Growth
content: If b > 1 in f(x) = ab^x, the function models exponential growth with rapid increase as x increases.

title: Properties of Exponential Decay
content: If 0 < b < 1 in f(x) = ab^x, the function models exponential decay with values decreasing toward zero.

title: Exponential Function Domain and Range
content: The domain is all real numbers, and the range is positive real numbers (y > 0) unless transformed.

title: Solving Exponential Equations (Same Base)
content: If both sides have the same base, set the exponents equal and solve: b^x = b^y → x = y.

title: Definition of Logarithm
content: The logarithm log_b(x) is the inverse of the exponential function: if b^y = x, then log_b(x) = y.

title: Common Logarithms and Natural Logarithms
content: log(x) is log base 10; ln(x) is log base e. These are standard on calculators.

title: Logarithmic Properties
content: Key properties include: log_b(xy) = log_b(x) + log_b(y), log_b(x/y) = log_b(x) − log_b(y), log_b(x^r) = r·log_b(x).

title: Change of Base Formula
content: log_b(x) = log_c(x) / log_c(b), typically used with base 10 or base e.

title: Solving Logarithmic Equations
content: Use properties of logarithms to combine terms, then convert to exponential form to solve.

title: Inverse Relationship of Exponential and Logarithmic Functions
content: f(x) = b^x and g(x) = log_b(x) are inverse functions: f(g(x)) = x and g(f(x)) = x.

title: Graph of Logarithmic Function
content: The graph of y = log_b(x) has a vertical asymptote at x = 0, domain x > 0, and passes through (1, 0).

title: Exponential Growth and Decay Modeling
content: Use f(t) = a·b^t to model exponential growth (b > 1) or decay (0 < b < 1). Identify initial value a and growth/decay factor b from context.

title: Domain Restriction in Logarithmic Equations
content: When solving log_b(x), the argument x must be positive. Always check solutions for domain validity.

title: Graph Interpretation of Exponential and Logarithmic Functions
content: Understand asymptotes, increasing/decreasing behavior, and key points like (0,1) for exponentials and (1,0) for logarithms.

title: Definition of Sequence
content: A sequence is an ordered list of numbers defined by a pattern or rule.

title: Arithmetic Sequence Definition
content: An arithmetic sequence has a common difference d between consecutive terms: a_n = a₁ + (n−1)d.

title: Geometric Sequence Definition
content: A geometric sequence has a common ratio r between consecutive terms: a_n = a₁·rⁿ⁻¹.

title: Explicit Formula for Arithmetic Sequence
content: a_n = a₁ + (n − 1)d, where a₁ is the first term and d is the common difference.

title: Explicit Formula for Geometric Sequence
content: a_n = a₁·rⁿ⁻¹, where a₁ is the first term and r is the common ratio.

title: Recursive Formula for Sequences
content: Defines each term based on the previous one: arithmetic → a_n = a_{n−1} + d, geometric → a_n = a_{n−1}·r.

title: Summation Notation (Sigma Notation)
content: Σ notation is used to represent the sum of a sequence: Σ_{i=1}^n a_i.

title: Sum of Geometric Series
content: S_n = a₁(1 − rⁿ) / (1 − r) for r ≠ 1.

title: Convergent Infinite Geometric Series
content: If |r| < 1, the sum of an infinite geometric series is S = a₁ / (1 − r).

title: Determining Sequence Type
content: To determine whether a sequence is arithmetic, geometric, or neither, examine the differences and ratios between consecutive terms.

title: Term Number from Sequence Formula
content: To find which term of a sequence a given value is, solve the explicit formula for n.

title: Using Sigma Notation for Arithmetic Series
content: Convert an arithmetic series into sigma notation by identifying the general term and limits of summation.

title: Using Sigma Notation for Geometric Series
content: Convert a geometric series into sigma notation by identifying the general term and ratio.

title: Recursive vs. Explicit Form Comparison
content: Recursive formulas define each term based on previous terms, while explicit formulas directly calculate any term from its position.

title: Modeling Real Situations with Sequences
content: Use arithmetic sequences for repeated addition and geometric sequences for repeated multiplication in real-world contexts like payments or population.

title: Non-Convergent Infinite Series
content: An infinite geometric series diverges if |r| ≥ 1 and has no finite sum.

title: Fundamental Counting Principle
content: If one event has m outcomes and another has n outcomes, then there are m × n total outcomes for both events.

title: Permutations Definition
content: A permutation is an arrangement of items where order matters. The number of permutations of n items is n!.

title: Permutation Formula
content: The number of permutations of n items taken r at a time is P(n, r) = n! / (n - r)!

title: Combinations Definition
content: A combination is a selection of items where order does not matter. The number of combinations is C(n, r) = n! / [r!(n - r)!].

title: Distinguishing Permutations and Combinations
content: Use permutations when order matters and combinations when it doesn’t.

title: Probability of an Event
content: Probability is the ratio of favorable outcomes to total outcomes: P(A) = (# favorable) / (# total).

title: Complement Rule
content: P(not A) = 1 - P(A).

title: Independent Events
content: Events A and B are independent if P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B).

title: Mutually Exclusive Events
content: Events A and B are mutually exclusive if they cannot both occur. P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B).

title: Conditional Probability
content: The probability of event A given that B has occurred is P(A | B) = P(A and B) / P(B).

title: Probability Tree Diagram
content: A tree diagram visually organizes multiple stages of probability events.

title: Mean, Median, Mode
content: Mean is the average; median is the middle value; mode is the most frequent value.

title: Range and Interquartile Range (IQR)
content: Range = max − min. IQR = Q3 − Q1, representing the middle 50% spread.

title: Standard Deviation (Concept)
content: Standard deviation measures how spread out the values in a data set are from the mean.

title: Outlier Definition
content: An outlier is a value significantly higher or lower than the rest. Often defined as 1.5×IQR above Q3 or below Q1.

title: Box-and-Whisker Plot
content: A graphical display that shows minimum, Q1, median, Q3, and maximum values of a data set.

title: Experimental vs. Theoretical Probability
content: Theoretical probability is based on known possible outcomes; experimental probability is based on observed outcomes from trials.

title: Probability of At Least One
content: Use the complement: P(at least one) = 1 − P(none).

title: Combinations with Replacement
content: When items are selected with replacement, they can be chosen again. The total combinations depend on whether order matters.

title: Venn Diagram for Probability
content: A Venn diagram helps visualize overlapping sets, unions, intersections, and complements in probability.

title: Expected Value
content: Expected value is the weighted average of all outcomes: E = Σ(probability × value).

title: Z-score (Standard Score)
content: A Z-score measures how many standard deviations a value is from the mean: z = (x − μ)/σ.

title: Definition of Binomial Experiment
content: A binomial experiment consists of a fixed number of independent trials, each with two possible outcomes: success or failure.

title: Binomial Probability Formula
content: P(k successes) = C(n, k) · p^k · (1 − p)^(n − k), where n is the number of trials and p is the probability of success.

title: Mean and Standard Deviation of Binomial Distribution
content: Mean = μ = np; Standard deviation = σ = √(np(1 − p)).

title: Normal Distribution Definition
content: A normal distribution is a symmetric, bell-shaped curve centered at the mean. Most values cluster around the center.

title: Empirical Rule (68-95-99.7 Rule)
content: In a normal distribution, ~68% of values lie within 1σ of the mean, 95% within 2σ, and 99.7% within 3σ.

title: Using Z-scores in Normal Distributions
content: Z-scores are used to find the relative position of a value in a normal distribution and to compute percentiles or probabilities.

content.definition: A point is a location with no dimension, represented by a dot and a capital letter.
A line is a straight path that extends infinitely in two directions and has one dimension.
A plane is a flat surface that extends infinitely in two dimensions and contains at least three non-collinear points.
A line segment is part of a line with two endpoints.
A ray starts at one point and extends infinitely in one direction.
Points that lie on the same line are collinear.
Points that lie on the same plane are coplanar.
The set of points that two or more geometric figures have in common.

title: Postulates about Points, Lines, and Planes

content.definition: Through any two points, there is exactly one line.
Through any three non-collinear points, there is exactly one plane.
If two points lie in a plane, then the line containing them lies in the plane.
If two lines intersect, they intersect in exactly one point. If two planes intersect, they intersect in a line.
The distance between two points is the absolute value of the difference of their coordinates.
Segments that have the same length are congruent.
If B is between A and C, then AB + BC = AC.
The midpoint of a segment is the point that divides the segment into two congruent parts.
A segment bisector is a point, ray, line, line segment, or plane that intersects a segment at its midpoint.
The distance between (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂) is √[(x₂ - x₁)² + (y₂ - y₁)²].
The midpoint of a segment with endpoints (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂) is ((x₁ + x₂)/2, (y₁ + y₂)/2).
An angle is formed by two rays with a common endpoint called the vertex.
The measure of an angle is typically expressed in degrees (°), with a full rotation equal to 360°.
If point B lies in the interior of ∠AOC, then m∠AOB + m∠BOC = m∠AOC.
An angle that measures greater than 0° and less than 90°.
An angle that measures exactly 90°.
An angle that measures greater than 90° and less than 180°.
An angle that measures exactly 180°.
Angles that have the same measure are congruent.
An angle bisector is a ray that divides an angle into two congruent angles.

title: Adjacent, Vertical, and Linear Pair Angles

content.definition: Two angles that share a common vertex and side but have no common interior points.
Angles opposite each other when two lines intersect. They are congruent.
A pair of adjacent angles whose non-common sides form a straight line. The angles are supplementary.
Two angles whose measures add up to 90°.
Two angles whose measures add up to 180°.
Two lines that intersect to form right angles.
Vertical angles are congruent, linear pairs are supplementary.
A triangle with no congruent sides.
A triangle with at least two congruent sides.
A triangle with all three sides congruent.
A triangle where all angles are less than 90°.
A triangle with one angle measuring exactly 90°.
A triangle with one angle greater than 90°.
The sum of the interior angles of a triangle is always 180°.
An exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the two remote interior angles.
Triangles that have the same size and shape, with corresponding sides and angles congruent.
If three sides of one triangle are congruent to three sides of another triangle, then the triangles are congruent.
If two sides and the included angle of one triangle are congruent to two sides and the included angle of another triangle, the triangles are congruent.
If two angles and the included side of one triangle are congruent to two angles and the included side of another triangle, the triangles are congruent.
If two angles and a non-included side of one triangle are congruent to the corresponding parts of another triangle, the triangles are congruent.
If two triangles are proven congruent, then their corresponding parts (sides and angles) are also congruent.
A triangle that has one right angle (90 degrees).
The side opposite the right angle in a right triangle; it is the longest side.
The two sides that form the right angle in a right triangle.
If the hypotenuse and a leg of one right triangle are congruent to the hypotenuse and a leg of another right triangle, then the triangles are congruent.
A triangle with at least two congruent sides.
If two sides of a triangle are congruent, then the angles opposite those sides are congruent.

title: Converse of the Isosceles Triangle Theorem

content.definition: If two angles of a triangle are congruent, then the sides opposite those angles are congruent.
A triangle with all three sides congruent and all three angles equal to 60 degrees.
An equilateral triangle is also equiangular, and all interior angles are 60 degrees.

title: Centroid Theorem
content: The centroid of a triangle divides each median into two segments, where the segment from the vertex to the centroid is twice as long as the segment from the centroid to the midpoint of the side.

title: Perpendicular Bisector Theorem
content: Any point on the perpendicular bisector of a segment is equidistant from the endpoints of the segment.

title: Converse of the Perpendicular Bisector Theorem
content: If a point is equidistant from the endpoints of a segment, then it lies on the perpendicular bisector of the segment.

title: Altitude of a Triangle
content: An altitude of a triangle is a perpendicular segment from a vertex to the line containing the opposite side.

title: Median of a Triangle
content: A median of a triangle is a segment connecting a vertex to the midpoint of the opposite side.

title: Angle Bisector of a Triangle
content: An angle bisector of a triangle is a ray or segment that divides one of the triangle's angles into two congruent angles and extends to the opposite side.

title: Concurrency of Altitudes Theorem
content: The three altitudes of a triangle intersect at a single point called the orthocenter.

title: Hinge Theorem (SAS Inequality Theorem)
content: If two sides of one triangle are congruent to two sides of another triangle, but the included angle of the first is larger, then the third side of the first triangle is longer than the third side of the second.

title: Converse of the Hinge Theorem
content: If two sides of one triangle are congruent to two sides of another triangle, and the third side of the first is longer than that of the second, then the included angle of the first is larger.

title: Concurrency of Medians Theorem
content: The medians of a triangle intersect at a single point called the centroid, which is located two-thirds of the distance from each vertex to the midpoint of the opposite side.

title: Circumcenter Theorem
content: The perpendicular bisectors of the sides of a triangle intersect at a point called the circumcenter, which is equidistant from the vertices of the triangle.

title: Incenter Theorem
content: The angle bisectors of a triangle intersect at a point called the incenter, which is equidistant from the sides of the triangle.

title: Triangle Midsegment Theorem
content: A midsegment of a triangle is parallel to one side of the triangle and its length is half the length of that side.

content.definition: A polygon with four sides and four angles.
A quadrilateral with both pairs of opposite sides parallel.
A parallelogram with four right angles.
A parallelogram with four congruent sides.
A parallelogram with four right angles and four congruent sides.
A quadrilateral with exactly one pair of parallel sides.
A line segment connecting non-consecutive vertices of a polygon.
In special quadrilaterals, diagonals have unique properties such as bisecting each other or being perpendicular.
Lines in the same plane that never intersect and are always the same distance apart.
A line that intersects two or more lines in a plane at different points.
Angles in matching corners when a transversal crosses two lines.
Angles on opposite sides of the transversal but inside the two lines.
Angles on the same side of the transversal and inside the two lines.

title: Parallel Lines and Angle Relationships Theorem
content: If a transversal intersects two parallel lines, then corresponding angles are congruent, alternate interior angles are congruent, and same-side interior angles are supplementary.

title: Corresponding Angles Postulate
content: If two parallel lines are cut by a transversal, then each pair of corresponding angles is congruent.

title: Alternate Interior Angles Theorem
content: If two parallel lines are cut by a transversal, then each pair of alternate interior angles is congruent.

title: Consecutive Interior Angles Theorem
content: If two parallel lines are cut by a transversal, then each pair of consecutive interior angles is supplementary.

title: Alternate Exterior Angles Theorem
content: If two parallel lines are cut by a transversal, then each pair of alternate exterior angles is congruent.

title: Converse of the Corresponding Angles Postulate
content: If two lines are cut by a transversal and corresponding angles are congruent, then the lines are parallel.

title: Converse of the Alternate Interior Angles Theorem
content: If two lines are cut by a transversal and alternate interior angles are congruent, then the lines are parallel.

title: Converse of the Consecutive Interior Angles Theorem
content: If two lines are cut by a transversal and consecutive interior angles are supplementary, then the lines are parallel.

title: Parallel Postulate
content: Through a point not on a line, there is exactly one line parallel to the given line.

title: Slopes of Parallel Lines
content: In a coordinate plane, two non-vertical lines are parallel if and only if they have the same slope.

title: Slopes of Perpendicular Lines
content: In a coordinate plane, two non-vertical lines are perpendicular if and only if the product of their slopes is –1.

title: Parallelogram Properties
content: A parallelogram is a quadrilateral with both pairs of opposite sides parallel. Opposite sides and angles are congruent, and diagonals bisect each other.

title: Conditions for Parallelograms
content: A quadrilateral is a parallelogram if one of the following is true: both pairs of opposite sides are congruent, both pairs of opposite angles are congruent, or the diagonals bisect each other.

title: Rectangle Definition and Properties
content: A rectangle is a parallelogram with four right angles. Its diagonals are congruent.

title: Rhombus Definition and Properties
content: A rhombus is a parallelogram with four congruent sides. Its diagonals are perpendicular and bisect opposite angles.

title: Square Definition and Properties
content: A square is a parallelogram with four right angles and four congruent sides. It is both a rectangle and a rhombus.

title: Trapezoid and Isosceles Trapezoid
content: A trapezoid is a quadrilateral with exactly one pair of parallel sides. An isosceles trapezoid has congruent legs and base angles.

title: Midsegment Theorem for Trapezoids
content: The midsegment of a trapezoid is parallel to the bases and its length is the average of the base lengths.

title: Kite Definition and Properties
content: A kite is a quadrilateral with two distinct pairs of adjacent congruent sides. One diagonal is the perpendicular bisector of the other.

title: Diagonals of Parallelograms
content: In a parallelogram, the diagonals bisect each other.

title: Polygon Definition
content: A polygon is a closed figure formed by a finite number of coplanar segments called sides that only intersect at their endpoints.

content.definition: A polygon that is both equilateral (all sides congruent) and equiangular (all angles congruent).
A polygon that is not regular.
A polygon with at least one interior angle greater than 180°.
A polygon where no interior angle is greater than 180°.

title: Interior Angle Sum Theorem
content: The sum of the interior angles of an n-gon is (n – 2) × 180°.

title: Exterior Angle Sum Theorem
content: The sum of the exterior angles of any polygon, one per vertex, is always 360°.

title: Each Interior Angle of a Regular Polygon
content: Each interior angle of a regular n-gon is [(n – 2) × 180°] / n.

title: Each Exterior Angle of a Regular Polygon
content: Each exterior angle of a regular n-gon is 360° / n.

content.definition: Each interior angle of a regular hexagon is 120°.
A regular hexagon can be divided into 6 equilateral triangles.
A regular hexagon has rotational symmetry of order 6 and 6 lines of symmetry.
Each interior angle of a regular octagon is 135°.
A regular octagon can be constructed using isosceles right triangles and squares.
A regular octagon has rotational symmetry of order 8 and 8 lines of symmetry.

title: Diagonal Count in Polygon
content: The number of diagonals in an n-gon is n(n – 3)/2.

content.definition: 3 sides
4 sides
5 sides
6 sides
7 sides
8 sides
9 sides
10 sides
11 sides
The apothem of a regular polygon is the perpendicular distance from the center of the polygon to a side. It is used to calculate the area of the polygon.
The area of a regular polygon can be found using the formula: (1/2) × Perimeter × Apothem.
A circle is the set of all points in a plane that are equidistant from a given point called the center.
A line segment from the center of the circle to any point on the circle.
A chord that passes through the center of the circle. It is twice the length of the radius.
A line segment with both endpoints on the circle.
A part of the circumference of a circle.
An angle whose vertex is the center of the circle and whose sides are radii.
The circumference of a circle is given by C = 2πr or C = πd, where r is the radius and d is the diameter.
The area of a circle is given by A = πr², where r is the radius.
Arc Length = (θ / 360) × 2πr, where θ is the central angle in degrees.
Sector Area = (θ / 360) × πr², where θ is the central angle in degrees.
An inscribed angle is half the measure of its intercepted arc.
The arc that lies in the interior of an inscribed angle and has endpoints on the angle.
A line that touches a circle at exactly one point.
The point where a tangent line touches the circle.

title: Tangent-Radius Theorem
content: A tangent to a circle is perpendicular to the radius drawn to the point of tangency.

title: Two Tangent Theorem
content: If two segments are drawn from the same external point to a circle and both are tangent to the circle, then the segments are congruent.

content.definition: In the same circle or in congruent circles, chords equidistant from the center are congruent.
A diameter or radius perpendicular to a chord bisects the chord and its arc.

title: Intersecting Chords Theorem
content: If two chords intersect inside a circle, then the products of the lengths of the segments of each chord are equal. That is, AE × EB = CE × ED.

title: Angle Formed by Two Intersecting Chords
content: The measure of an angle formed by two intersecting chords is equal to half the sum of the measures of the arcs intercepted by the angle and its vertical angle.

title: Angle Formed by a Tangent and a Chord
content: The measure of an angle formed by a tangent and a chord drawn to the point of tangency is half the measure of the intercepted arc.

title: Angles Formed Outside the Circle
content: If two secants, a secant and a tangent, or two tangents intersect outside a circle, the measure of the angle formed is half the difference of the measures of the intercepted arcs.

title: Power of a Point Theorem
content: If a secant and a tangent are drawn from an external point, then the square of the length of the tangent segment equals the product of the lengths of the secant segment and its external part.

title: Cyclic Quadrilateral Theorem
content: If a quadrilateral is inscribed in a circle, then its opposite angles are supplementary.

title: Central Angle Theorem
content: The measure of a central angle is equal to the measure of the arc it intercepts.

content.definition: An arc that measures less than 180° and is named with two letters.
An arc that measures more than 180° and is named with three letters.
A transformation is a function that moves or changes a geometric figure in some way to produce a new figure.
A translation slides every point of a figure the same distance in the same direction.
In the coordinate plane, a translation of (x, y) by (a, b) is given by (x + a, y + b).
A reflection flips a figure over a line, creating a mirror image.
Over x-axis: (x, y) → (x, –y), over y-axis: (x, y) → (–x, y), over y = x: (x, y) → (y, x)
A rotation turns a figure around a fixed point called the center of rotation.
90° counterclockwise: (x, y) → (–y, x), 180°: (x, y) → (–x, –y), 270°: (x, y) → (y, –x)
A dilation changes the size of a figure but not its shape, based on a scale factor from a center.
With center at origin and scale factor k: (x, y) → (kx, ky)
A transformation that preserves distance and angle measure (e.g., translations, reflections, rotations).
A transformation that changes the size but preserves shape and angle measures (e.g., dilation, or dilation + rigid motion).

title: Congruence via Transformations
content: Two figures are congruent if one can be mapped to the other using a sequence of rigid motions.

title: Similarity via Transformations
content: Two figures are similar if one can be mapped to the other using a sequence of rigid motions followed by a dilation.

content.definition: The result of applying two or more transformations in succession.
A two-dimensional plane formed by the intersection of a horizontal number line (x-axis) and a vertical number line (y-axis).
A pair of numbers (x, y) that indicate the position of a point on the coordinate plane.
The point (0, 0) where the x-axis and y-axis intersect.
The distance between points (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂) is √[(x₂ - x₁)² + (y₂ - y₁)²].
The midpoint of a segment with endpoints (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂) is ((x₁ + x₂)/2, (y₁ + y₂)/2).
The slope of a line through points (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂) is (y₂ - y₁) / (x₂ - x₁).
The equation of a line in the form y = mx + b, where m is the slope and b is the y-intercept.
The equation of a line through point (x₁, y₁) with slope m is y - y₁ = m(x - x₁).
The equation of a line in the form Ax + By = C, where A, B, and C are real numbers and A and B are not both zero.
Two lines are parallel if they have the same slope and different y-intercepts.
Two lines are perpendicular if the product of their slopes is –1.
Use distance formula to show all corresponding sides are equal.
Use slope to show two sides are perpendicular.
Use distance formula to show two sides are congruent.
Opposite sides are parallel (same slope) and congruent (same length).
All angles are right angles (perpendicular sides) and opposite sides are congruent.
All sides are congruent and diagonals are perpendicular.
All sides congruent, all angles right.

title: Using Slope to Show Collinearity
content: Three points are collinear if the slopes between each pair of points are equal.

title: Using Slope and Distance to Prove Figures
content: You can use slope to check parallelism or perpendicularity, and distance to verify congruence or lengths, in order to classify triangles and quadrilaterals.

title: Using Midpoint to Show Bisection
content: If the midpoint of a segment coincides with the midpoint of another, it shows that both segments bisect each other.

title: Verifying Diagonal Properties with Coordinates
content: To prove diagonals bisect each other, show they share the same midpoint. To prove perpendicular diagonals, show the slopes are negative reciprocals.

title: Equation of a Circle
content: The standard form of a circle with center (h, k) and radius r is (x - h)² + (y - k)² = r².

title: Locus Definition of a Circle
content: A circle is the set of all points in a plane equidistant from a fixed point called the center.

title: Distance from a Point to a Line
content: The distance from a point (x₀, y₀) to a line Ax + By + C = 0 is |Ax₀ + By₀ + C| / √(A² + B²).

content.definition: A solid with two congruent circular bases connected by a curved surface.

title: Surface Area and Volume of a Cylinder

content.definition: SA = 2πr² + 2πrh, where r is the radius and h is the height.
V = πr²h
A solid with a circular base and a vertex not in the same plane as the base.

title: Surface Area and Volume of a Cone

content.definition: SA = πr² + πrl, where r is the radius and l is the slant height.
V = 1/3 πr²h, where h is the height of the cone.
A sphere is the set of all points in space that are a given distance (radius) from a given point (center).

title: Surface Area and Volume of a Sphere

content.definition: SA = 4πr², where r is the radius of the sphere.
V = 4/3 πr³
A circle formed by the intersection of a sphere and a plane that contains the center of the sphere.
Half of a sphere, formed by cutting a sphere with a plane through its center.
V = 2/3 πr³
A solid figure composed of two or more simple solid figures.

title: Surface Area of Composite Solids
content: The surface area of a composite solid is found by adding the surface areas of its individual components, subtracting any hidden or shared faces.

content.definition: A three-dimensional figure obtained by rotating a two-dimensional shape around an axis.
Rotating a rectangle around one side creates a cylinder; rotating a triangle creates a cone.
In a right triangle, the sine of an angle is the ratio of the length of the opposite side to the hypotenuse.
In a right triangle, the cosine of an angle is the ratio of the length of the adjacent side to the hypotenuse.
In a right triangle, the tangent of an angle is the ratio of the length of the opposite side to the adjacent side.
The reciprocal of sine: hypotenuse divided by opposite side.
The reciprocal of cosine: hypotenuse divided by adjacent side.
The reciprocal of tangent: adjacent side divided by opposite side.

title: SOH-CAH-TOA Mnemonic
content: SOH-CAH-TOA helps remember sine, cosine, and tangent: Sine = Opposite/Hypotenuse, Cosine = Adjacent/Hypotenuse, Tangent = Opposite/Adjacent.

title: Using Trigonometry to Find Side Lengths
content: Given an angle and one side of a right triangle, trigonometric ratios can be used to calculate the unknown side lengths.

title: Using Trigonometry to Find Angles
content: Given two side lengths of a right triangle, inverse trigonometric functions can be used to find the measures of the non-right angles.

title: Translation Property by Addition
content: Adding the same quantity to both sides of an equation preserves equality.

title: Translation Property by Subtraction
content: Subtracting the same quantity from both sides of an equation preserves equality.

title: Substitution Property
content: If two quantities are equal, one may be substituted for the other in any expression or equation.

title: Transitive Property of Equality
content: If a = b and b = c, then a = c.

title: Reflexive Property of Equality
content: Any quantity is equal to itself: a = a.

title: Symmetric Property of Equality
content: If a = b, then b = a.

title: Distributive Property
content: Multiplying a number by a sum is the same as multiplying each addend individually and then adding the products: a(b + c) = ab + ac.

title: Pythagorean Theorem
content: In a right triangle, the square of the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares of the legs: a² + b² = c².

title: Triangle Area Formula
content: The area of a triangle is one-half the base times the height: A = 1/2 × base × height.

title: Definition of a Function
content: A function is a relation in which each input has exactly one output. It can be represented using equations, graphs, or mappings.

title: Domain and Range of a Function
content: The domain is the set of all possible input values, and the range is the set of all corresponding output values of a function.

title: Function Notation
content: Function notation f(x) represents the output of function f for input x. The expression f(a) means the value of the function at a.

title: Vertical Line Test for Functions
content: A graph represents a function if and only if no vertical line intersects the graph at more than one point.

title: Piecewise-defined Function
content: A piecewise-defined function is defined by different expressions over different parts of its domain.

title: Even and Odd Functions
content: A function is even if f(−x) = f(x) for all x in its domain, and odd if f(−x) = −f(x).

title: Increasing, Decreasing, Constant Intervals
content: A function is increasing on intervals where its graph rises, decreasing where it falls, and constant where it is flat.

title: Local and Absolute Extrema
